awd_titl_txt: Cybertraining: Pilot: Collaborative Research:  Cybertraining for Earth Surface Processes Modelers
awd_abstract_narration:
Living sustainably on a rapidly changing planet is one of the greatest modern scientific and societal challenges. One critical aspect of global change involves the earth's surface itself: the rearrangement of its landforms, soils, and sediments by processes such as landslides, debris flows, floods, and coastal erosion. The Community Surface Dynamics Modeling System, CSDMS, creates cyberinfrastructure to enable advanced numerical models of the earth's surface, its changes through time, and the influence of human activity. However, traditional earth science education does not usually equip students with skills to become effective cyberinfrastructure users and cyberinfrastructure contributors. In order to develop innovative models for analyzing and predicting how the earth's surface responds to environmental change and human influence, the earth surface processes (ESP) modeling community needs a platform to teach modern programming practices and High Performance Computing methods. This project implements a 10-day Cyberinfrastructure in Earth Surface Processes Institute (ESPIn) for graduate students, postdoctoral fellows and early career faculty at the CSDMS Integration Facility at the University of Colorado in Boulder in the summers of 2020-2021 trains the next generation to be innovators. ESPIn aims to transcend the traditional model of department-based graduate education through interdisciplinary, problem-based, "Just in Time Teaching" of model use and development. Over forty participants, selected from diverse disciplinary backgrounds with explicit slots reserved for underrepresented minorities, gain direct experience in converting their research codes into open-source distributed software. ESPIn hosts developed lesson material in online open access educational repositories. ESPIn helps to train a new generation of computationally savvy, integrative scientists, while accomplishing major community science priorities. This project thus serves the national interest, as stated by NSF's mission: to promote the progress of science; to advance the national prosperity and welfare by building a capable geoscience workforce.

The Earth Surface Processes Institute (ESPIn) is a 10-day immersive experience for graduate students, postdoctoral fellows and early career faculty, allowing them to make advances on critical earth surface processes research questions with state-of-the-art modeling tools. This project targets learners who would benefit from critical knowledge, skills, and tools to become better cyberinfrastructure users and developers through a careful, inclusive selection procedure. This project aims to help make scientific advances in the study of Earth Surface Processes (ESP) that leverage the powerful and advanced capabilities of new cybertools, such as the Python Modeling Tool. To these ends, the primary objective is to expand the use of cyberinfrastructure among members of the ESP research community with training that (1) increases their competence and confidence with using cyberinfrastructure tools, methods, and resources and (2) moves the larger ESP community towards more widely adopting tools to advance the fundamental science of predicting surface change.  Experienced scientists, visiting faculty, and software engineers assist with training and mentoring of the participants. ESPIn offers hands-on training in best programming practices, numerical methods, open source software development, advanced use of version control systems, writing unit tests, HPC-based sensitivity testing and model uncertainty quantification techniques. Several days are dedicated to working collaboratively on research and coding projects. Participants work on developing their own codes, with the intent of making codes more robust and compliant with existing ESP CI frameworks. The Summer Institute is quantitatively evaluated for learning efficacy and evaluations are used to iterate on lesson material quality. ESPIn provides all developed lesson material as online learning and teaching modules and broadly advertises these resources to the geoscience community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Living sustainably on a rapidly changing planet is an immense scientific and societal challenge. One facet of global change involves the dynamic earth’s surface itself: the continuous rearrangement of its landforms, soils, and sediments by processes such as floods, landslides, post-fire mass movements and coastal erosion. Recent major disasters highlight the need for advanced computational models capable of forecasting earth surface changes and as such contribute to design of sustainable solutions.

The Community Surface Dynamics Modeling System, CSDMS, consists of over 2300 scientists and creates cyberinfrastructure to enable computer modeling of the earth’s surface, its changes through time, and the influence of human activity. However, traditional earth science education does not usually equip students with the skills to become effective model users or developers. In order to develop innovative models for analyzing and predicting how the earth’s surface responds to environmental change and human influence, the earth surface processes community critically needed a platform to teach modern software development practices.

To address this need, this pilot project created a 10-day Cyberinfrastructure Earth Surface Processes Institute (ESPIn). ESPIn has been organized for 79 graduate students, postdoctoral fellows and early career faculty at the University of Colorado in Boulder in the summers of 2020-2022. Out of necessity, ESPIn was run fully online in the two pandemic summers of 2020 and 2021, but with utmost care to offer full day tutorial and coding activities and still allow for professional networking and close interactions of the participants. Then, in 2022 ESPIn transitioned to a 10-day in-person event, combined with the annual meeting of CSDMS.

ESPIn aimed to have diverse participants and has strived to include students from groups that have traditionally been underrepresented in geoscience. ESPIn has been broadly advertised throughout the community, and explicitly reached out to faculty at minority-serving institutions to encourage a broad group of applicants. ESPIn typically has received 90-100 applications for ~25 slots. The project team designed a careful (blind) review system to minimize bias in selection, which has resulted in diversity in gender, ethnicity, race and participant’s backgrounds. Over 2020-2022, the selected participants have 

The program of the summer institute included hands-on tutorials on shell scripting, python coding, numerical methods, teamwork on coding projects, science lectures by fellow modelers, and software developers. ESPIn also included professional development and career discussions and networking activities. Graduates of early ESPIn years have been assiting the participants as peer-mentors in subsequent years, with a cross-generational network of modelers evolving.

All curriculum materials for learning python programming, numerical modeling, use of community cyberinfrastructure tools, and best practices in research code development to help rising geoscientists develop better scientific software are open-source and are available for others to use in their own learning or teaching.  This collection of digital learning materials is widely available, as a digital collection known as CSDMS Ivy. The CSDMS Ivy course material is designed such that the lessons can be viewed and run on the community OpenEarthscape JupyterHub, a free computing resource for members. However, the lessons can also be used exclusively on a local machine.

This cybertraining project was a 2-year pilot, but its success has been recognized by the CSDMS community and its steering committee. Organization of similar summer institutes for the next generation of graduate students and early career scientists is now integrated into the core CSDMS activities for 2023-2027 and funded by the NSF Geoinformatics program.
